. ODE VI.

TO APOLLO.

GREAr god, whose bow, in anger strung, Aveng'd proud Niobe’s boastful tongue, Punish'd lewd Tityus’ lustful fleme,

Α And Troy’s victorious foe could tame,

Brevest of Greeks -yet less than thee, Though Thetis own’d her progeny 3 Before whose proudly·brandish’d spear The Darden turrets ehook with sear: He- as opine by woodman’s blow, Or cypress leid by Eurus low -

Falls wide along the extended plain, Whom Trojan mud and dust distein. Not he, enclos'd with lying crowd,

In horse -to Pallas falsely vow'd -
